qas.question: What special protection are most PCBs shipped in?
What's another term for "grounded" in the context of PCBs?
What force can easily change or even completely destroy an etch on a PCB?
What class of PCBs are even more susceptible to static than standard ones?
Non-traditional PCBs include microwave PCBs and what other type of board?
Many assembled PABs are sensitive to what?

plausible_answers.text: an accumulated static charge through the board

qas.question: Proper handling techniques might transmit what?
What must be placed in static bags during transport?
An accumulated static charge though the user happens when what is done?

context: Many <b7_0>assembled PCBs<b7_0/> are <b5_0>static<b5_0/> sensitive, and therefore must be placed in <a0_0>antistatic bags<a0_0/> during transport. When handling these boards, the user must be grounded (<a1_0>earthed<a1_0/>). <b8_0>Improper handling techniques<b8_0/> might transmit <b6_0>an accumulated static charge through the board<b6_0/>, damaging or destroying components. Even bare boards are sometimes static sensitive. Traces have become so fine that it's quite possible to blow an etch off the board (or change its characteristics) with a <a2_0>static charge<a2_0/>. This is especially true on <a3_0>non-traditional<a3_0/> PCBs such as <a4_0>MCMs<a4_0/> and microwave PCBs.
